summary: respiratory diseases are a major contributor to morbidity and mortality in many tropical countries, including laos. emergence of sARS in 2003 followed by outbreaks of the highly pathogenic avian influenza (HPAI) H5N1 in 2015. despite improvements in surveillance capacity for respiratory disease and influenza virus in many low- and middle-income countries, there remain many challenges and knowledge gaps. influenza (12%), parainfluenza viruses (9%), adenoviruses (6%), human metapneumovirus (6%), and corona viruses (4%) and human Bocavirus (HboV) were the main bacterial pathogens causing ALRI in hospitalized children. the national immunoization program (NIP) in laos has made considerable progress since 2009. laCoRIS is a community-based study that monitors the etiology and burden of respiratory disease among residents of this region. the project was initiated in 2015 as an extension of surveillance activities initially set up by coPanFlu project in 2009–2010. the primary objectives of the project were to measure the incidence rates of acute respiratory diseases and to identify their etiologic pathogens in metropolitan Vientiane. the suspected ILI cases were first identified using the WHO case definition as either > 37.5°C axillary temperature or > 38°C tympanic temperature with an associated respiratory symptom. a follow-up questionnaire was administrated to all ILI cases approximately 60 days following the disease onset. PCR positive cases of Streptococcus pneumoniae were serotyped for 40 different serotypes by using a novel multiplex real-time PCR assay. the method identifies the following serotypes: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6A/B, 6C, 7C, 7F, 8, 9N/L, 9V, 10A, 10F, 11A, 12F, 13, 14, 15A, 15B/C, 16F, 17F, 18F, 19 sputum was stained by Gram stain and the Kinyoun method for acid-fast bacilli. sputum was cultured on goat blood agar with an optochin disc, chocolate agar and Ashdown agar and broth for Burkholderia pseudomallei. three binary outcome variables were used, based on whether the participant experienced at least one episode of ILI, virus-positive ILI, and bacteria-positive ILI during the surveillance period. the final multivariate models were then derived through backwards, stepwise elimination of variables which did not retain statistical significance of P0.1 based on ANOVA. a household-level questionnaire was administered to collect data on socio-economic and potential exposure-related variables. individual-level data were collected on subject age, sex, pre-existing medical conditions and influenza vaccination history within the past 12 months. three H. influenzae cultures tested, 66.7% were resistant to ampicillin. this is the first community-based surveillance that prospectively monitored the incidence of ILI and its causative pathogens in Vientiane capital in lao PDR. a higher incidence of respiratory infections in lower SES households have been reported in several studies and is thought to be related to overcrowding. our estimate of ILI incidence of 0.11 episodes per person-year is very similar to the rate reported in a household surveillance study in Vietnam [34]. a known virus or bacterium was identified by the PCR-based assay in 65.1% of the 548 nasal swabs samples, and by microbial culture in 8.6% and 45.9% of throat and sputum specimens respectively. a previous in vivo study found that live attenuated influenza vaccine promotes colonisation by Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus aureus of the upper respiratory tracts of mice. previous studies reported no association between LAIV and nasal carriage of bacteria in humans. one observation of note was the complete absence of B. pseudomallei, which has previously been reported to cause a mild, self-limiting ‘flu-like illness in northern Australia [43], in this population. coronaviruses found in children 0–4 and 5–14 years old respectively. highest rates of Streptococcus pneumoniae carriage are in general seen at 6 months to 3 years of age. inverse relationship has previously been observed between carriage of Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus aureus. in the 14 potential household transmission events identified, the “index” cases were children in less than half of the clusters. the findings are consistent with those of the household cohort study in Vietnam. however, the limitations of community-based ILI surveillance should be acknowledged. despite these limitations, our study has provided comprehensive insights on the etiology and incidence of ILI in laos. the major strength of this study is that it considered a much more comprehensive range of pathogens than is typically covered in ILI surveillance studies. the study could also have some direct benefits for the study population. incidence estimates are adjusted for the demographic structure of the Laos urban household population in 2015.
